Description: Painted limestone shabti of Qenherkhepeshef: showing a mummiform figure holding agricultural implements. The hieroglyphic text is skilfully painted in horizontal lines of black around the mummiform body. The nose is chipped and some paint has been lost from the face.
Curator's comments: As shabtis were substitutes for the deceased, they also act as representations of the person, but the features of the figurine are so standardized that they cannot be considered a portrait. Nevertheless this is the only known representation of the well-known scribe. Bibliography: M. Bierbrier, 'The Tomb-builders of the Pharaohs' (Cairo, 1989 [1st edn 1982]), 12, fig.3.
Bibliographic references: Parkinson 1999 / Cracking Codes: The Rosetta Stone and Decipherment (70)
Exhibition history: 2015, 19th June - 5th Sept. Wrexham County Borough Museum. Egyptian Written Culture. 2016 12 Mar-8 May, Carlisle, Tullie House, Writing for Eternity 2016 20 May-4 Sept, The Salisbury Museum, Writing for Eternity 2016 16 Sept-10 Jan 2017, Abergavenny Museum, Writing for Eternity 2017 21 Jan-21 May, Museum of Hartlepool, Writing for Eternity
Condition: good. The nose is chipped and some paint has been lost from the face.
